Geopolitically, it has the potential to be a game changer."<ref>[http://www.consilium.europa.eu/en/press/press-releases/2015/07/14-tusk-statement-agreement-iran/ "Statement by President Donald Tusk on the agreement on Iran's nuclear programme"], European Council (15 July 2015).</ref> * {{flagu|France}} ** In a [[Bastille Day]] speech, [[President of France|President]] [[Francois Hollande]] praised the deal and called upon Iran to "show that it is ready to help us end" the [[Syrian civil war]].<ref name="Hollande">Associated Press, [https://www.usnews.com/news/world/articles/2015/07/14/hollande-calls-on-iran-to-help-in-syrian-conflict "French President Hollande calls on Iran to help in Syrian conflict"] U.S. News & World Report (14 July 2015).</ref> French Foreign Minister [[Laurent Fabius]] told ''[[Le Monde]]'' that the pact was a "robust agreement" that would last at least a decade.<ref name="Fabius">[http://economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/international/business/iran-deal-sufficiently-robust-for-10-years-says-frances-foreign-minister-laurent-fabius/articleshow/48068401.cms "Iran deal 'sufficiently robust' for 10 years, says France's foreign minister Laurent Fabius"], ''The Economic Times'', Reuters (14 July 2015).</ref> Both Hollande and Fabius pledged that France would be "extremely vigilant" in the implementation of the agreement.<ref name="Hollande" /><ref name="Fabius" /> ** Fabius visited Iran on 29 July, telling reporters in Tehran, "this deal allows the [[Iran-France relations|relations between our countries]] to develop and allows us to renew cooperation." His visit was controversial in Iran and met with public anger for several reasons.<ref name="ErdbrinkFabius">Thomas Erdbrink, [https://www.nytimes.com/2015/07/30/world/middleeast/french-foreign-minister-laurent-fabius-tehran.html "Laurent Fabius, French Foreign Minister, Visits Iran"], ''The New York Times'' (29 July 2015).</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.al-monitor.com/pulse/originals/2015/07/fabius-trip-tehran-infected-blood-hiv.html |title=Fabius visit stirs bad blood in Iran |publisher=Al-Monitor |accessdate=3 August 2015}}</ref> * {{flagu|Germany}} ** [[Chancellor of Germany (1949–)|Chancellor]] [[Angela Merkel]] said that the agreement was "an important success" of international diplomacy.<ref name="Relief" /> ** Vice Chancellor and Economy Minister [[Sigmar Gabriel]] said that the agreement was a "historic breakthrough".<ref name="DW">[http://www.dw.com/en/gabriel-heads-off-to-forge-business-links-with-iran/a-18593967 Gabriel heads off to forge business links with Iran], Deutsche Welle (19 July 2015).</ref> In mid-July 2015, Gabriel, along with a delegation of German industry and science representatives, completed a three-day visit to Iran focused on bolstering German-Iranian trade.<ref name="DW"/> Gabriel said there was "great interest on the part of German industry in normalizing and strengthening economic relations with Iran".<ref name="DW"/> * {{flagu|Iran}} ** Iranian Supreme Leader Khamenei who initially issued a letter of guidelines to President Rouhani, ordering him on how to proceed with the deal,<ref name="memri.org">{{cite web|url=https://www.memri.org/reports/iranian-supreme-leader-khameneis-letter-guidelines-president-rohani-jcpoa-sets-nine|title=Iranian Supreme Leader Khamenei's Letter Of Guidelines To President Rohani On JCPOA Sets Nine Conditions Nullifying Original Agreement Announced July 14, 2015|publisher=MEMRI |accessdate=6 January 2018}}</ref><ref name="jpost.com">{{cite news |url=http://www.jpost.com/Middle-East/Expert-Khameneis-letter-to-Rouhani-voids-deal-430056|title=Expert: Khamenei's letter to Rouhani voids deal|newspaper=The Jerusalem Post |accessdate=6 January 2018}}</ref> threatened to 'set fire' to nuclear deal if West violates.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-iran-nuclear-khamenei/irans-khamenei-threatens-to-set-fire-to-nuclear-deal-if-west-violates-idUSKCN0Z02MA|title=Iran's Khamenei threatens to 'set fire' to nuclear deal if West violat|date=14 June 2016 |publisher=Reuters |accessdate=6 January 2018}}</ref> [[President of Iran|President]] [[Hassan Rouhani]] said the final agreement proved that "constructive engagement works" and presented the deal as a step on the road towards a wider goal of international cooperation: "With this unnecessary crisis resolved, new horizons emerge with a focus on shared challenges."<ref name="Hafezi" /> ** [[Foreign Affairs Minister of Iran|Minister of Foreign Affairs]] [[Mohammad Javad Zarif]] called it an "historic moment" and said: "Today could have been the end of hope on this issue, but now we are starting a new chapter of hope. Let's build on that."<ref>Reuters, [https://www.reuters.com/article/2015/07/14/us-nuclear-iran-deal-idUSKCN0PO0UV20150714 "Iran's Zarif, EU say nuclear deal is new chapter of hope"] (16 July 2015).</ref> ** In a 21 July speech to the Iranian Parliament, Zarif said that the agreement was a defeat for Israel, saying, "Never before was the Zionist regime so isolated, even among her own allies."<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.haaretz.com/news/diplomacy-defense/1.667046 |title=Iran Calls Nuclear Deal Great Defeat for Israel: 'Never Has the Zionist Regime Been So Isolated' |agency=Reuters |newspaper=[[Haaretz]] |date=21 July 2015}}</ref> On 12 August, after a meeting with [[Hizbullah]] leader [[Hassan Nasrallah]], Zarif said that the agreement "created a historic opportunity to [sic] for regional cooperation to fight extremism and face threats posed by the Zionist entity".<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.timesofisrael.com/zarif-in-beirut-nuke-deal-historic-opportunity-to-face-israeli-threats/ |title=Zarif in Beirut: Nuke deal 'historic opportunity' to face Israeli threats |author=Newman, Marissa}}</ref> ** Many Iranian families and youth celebrated at [[Vanak]] Square and elsewhere on the streets of Tehran on the evening of the agreement's announcements.<ref name="ErdbrinkReact">Thomas Erdbrink, [https://www.nytimes.com/2015/07/15/world/middleeast/iran-celebrates-nuclear-deal-tempered-by-cynicism-and-hard-liner-warnings.html "Iran Celebrates Nuclear Deal, Tempered by Cynicism and Hard-Liner Warnings"], ''The New York Times'' (14 July 2015).</ref> Some held signs calling for the release of Iranian opposition leaders [[Mir Hussein Moussavi]] and [[Mehdi Karroubi]] from house arrest.<ref name="ErdbrinkReact" /> Other ordinary Iranians cheered the announcement on social media.<ref name="ErdbrinkReact" /> ** On 16 July 2015, two days after the agreement was signed, [[Supreme Leader of Iran|Iran's supreme leader]], Ayatollah [[Ali Khamenei]], made his first public comments on the final agreement in a letter to President Hassan Rouhani posted on Khamenei's website.<ref name="Khamenei">Thomas Erdbrink, [https://www.nytimes.com/2015/07/16/world/middleeast/supreme-leader-ali-khamenei-urges-careful-scrutiny-of-iran-deal.html?ref=middleeast "Supreme Leader Ali Khamenei Urges 'Careful Scrutiny' of Iran Deal"], ''The New York Times'' (15 July 2015).</ref> Khamenei wrote, "bringing the negotiations to a conclusion was a milestone" but, "the prepared text, however, needs careful scrutiny".<ref name="Khamenei" /> Iranian hard-liners took the letter as a signal of openness to criticize the deal.<ref name="Khamenei" /><ref name="Hardliner" /> In a speech in Tehran marking the end of Ramadan made two days later, Khamenei said, "Our policies toward the arrogant government of the United States will not be changed at all,"<ref name="Dareini">Ali Akbar Dareini, [https://www.nytimes.com/aponline/2015/07/18/world/middleeast/ap-ml-iran-nuclear.html "Iran's Supreme Leader Says Nuclear Deal Won't Change Policy Toward 'Arrogant' U.S."], ''The New York Times'', Associated Press (18 July 2015).</ref> adding, "the Americans say they stopped Iran from acquiring a nuclear weapon ... They know it's not true. We had [[Khamenei's fatwa against nuclear weapons|a fatwa, declaring nuclear weapons to be religiously forbidden]] under Islamic law. It had nothing to do with the nuclear talks."<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2015/07/iran-nuclear-deal-150718051925210.html |title=Khamenei: Opposition to US persists after nuclear deal}}</ref> However, Khamenei also praised the negotiators who arranged the deal, which was taken as a symbol that he would not seek to block the deal in the [[Islamic Consultative Assembly|Iranian parliament]] or the [[Supreme National Security Council]].<ref name="Dareini" /> Khamenei also expressed support for the agreement, saying: "After 12 years of struggling with the Islamic republic, the result is that they [the P5+1 nations] have to bear the turning of thousands of centrifuges in the country."<ref>Thomas Erdbrink, [https://www.nytimes.com/2015/07/19/world/middleeast/ayatollah-ali-khamenei-of-iran-backs-negotiators-and-doesnt-criticize-nuclear-deal.html "Ayatollah Khamenei, Backing Iran Negotiators, Endorses Nuclear Deal"], ''The New York Times'' (18 July 2015).</ref> Khamenei is believed to have approved the negotiations and the agreement, giving Rouhani crucial political cover to do so.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Wiklin |first1=Sam |title=Iran's Khamenei lent cautious support to pursuit of nuclear deal |url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/2015/07/14/uk-iran-nuclear-khamenei-idUKKCN0PO0V520150714 |accessdate=17 July 2015 |publisher=Reuters |date=14 July 2015}}</ref> ** ''The New York Times'' reported, "Iran's influential hard-liners, who have criticized Mr. Rouhani in much the same way that President Obama has been denounced by Republicans in the United States, signaled their intent to undercut the agreement," which they believe to be too favorable to the West.<ref name="ErdbrinkReact" /> Foad Izadi, a professor at the [[University of Tehran]], complained that of the 19 Iranian "major red lines" identified by the supreme leader during negotiations, "18 and a half have been crossed."<ref name="Hardliner">Thomas Erdbrink, [https://www.nytimes.com/2015/07/17/world/middleeast/iranian-hard-liners-say-nuclear-accord-crosses-their-red-lines.html "Iranian Hard-Liners Say Nuclear Accord Crosses Their Red Lines"], ''The New York Times'' (16 July 2015).</ref> Conservative lawmaker [[Alireza Zakani]] said "celebrating too early can send a bad signal to the enemy."<ref name="Hafezi" /> ** Iran's official [[Islamic Republic News Agency]] stressed that under the agreement "world powers have recognized Iran's peaceful nuclear program and are to respect the nuclear rights of (Iran) within international conventions."<ref name="Botelho">Greg Botelho, [http://www.cnn.com/2015/07/14/politics/iran-nuclear-deal-highlights/ "Iran nuclear deal full of complex issues and moving parts"], CNN (14 July 2015).</ref> The IRNA report also said, "The policy on preventing enrichment uranium is now failed" and stressed, "no Iranian nuclear facilities or centrifuges will be dismantled."<ref name="Botelho"/> * {{flagu|Russian Federation}} ** [[President of Russia|President]] [[Vladimir Putin]] said in a statement: "We are certain that the world heaved a sigh of relief today." ** [[Minister of Foreign Affairs (Russia)|Foreign Minister]] [[Sergei Lavrov]] stated the accord "will favorably affect the general situation in the Middle East, North Africa and the Gulf".<ref>Maria Stromova & Alastair Jamieson, [http://www.nbcnews.com/storyline/iran-nuclear-talks/iran-nuclear-deal-russia-hails-positive-step-middle-east-n391686 "Iran Nuclear Deal: Russia Hails 'Positive Step' for Middle East"], NBC News (14 July 2015).</ref><ref name="clairephipps" /> * {{flagu|United Kingdom}} ** Prime Minister [[David Cameron]] applauded the agreement, saying that it would help "make our world a safer place" and that Iran now had a "real opportunity" to benefit economically.<ref name="Relief">Robin Millard, [https://news.yahoo.com/world-leaders-voice-relief-iran-nuclear-deal-141113251.html "World leaders voice relief at Iran nuclear deal"], Yahoo! News, AFP (14 July 2015).</ref> ** [[Secretary of State for Foreign and Commonwealth Affairs|Foreign Secretary]] [[Philip Hammond]] criticized the Israeli government's position on the JCPOA, saying in the [[House of Commons of the United Kingdom|House of Commons]], "no agreement with Iran would have been enough for Netanyahu" and "Israel prefers a permanent state of standoff" with Iran.<ref>Barak Ravid, [http://www.haaretz.com/news/diplomacy-defense/.premium-1.666143 "Israel prefers permanent standoff to any Iran deal, says U.K.'s foreign secretary"], ''Haaretz'' (15 July 2015).</ref><ref name="Hammond">Associated Press, [https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/jul/16/netanyahu-hammond-spar-iran-nuclear-agreement "Netanyahu and Hammond spar over Iran nuclear agreement"], ''The Guardian'' (16 July 2015).</ref> At a joint press conference the next day in Jerusalem, Hammond and Netanyahu "sparred publicly" over the agreement, "veering off prepared comments ... in an awkward back-and-forth that extended what is usually a standard, brief public appearance with visiting officials into a spirited debate".<ref name="Hammond" /> * {{flagu|United States}} ** President [[Barack Obama]] addressed the nation in a 7 a.m. televised address from the [[White House]], with Vice President [[Joe Biden]] at his side.<ref>Ray Locker, [https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/world/2015/07/14/obama-winning-streak-iran-deal/30123245/ "First take: Obama's winning streak continues with Iran deal"], ''USA Today'' (14 July 2015).</ref><ref name="Lewis">Paul Lewis, [https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/jul/14/obama-veto-republican-iran-nuclear-deal "Obama vows to veto any Republican attempt to derail Iran nuclear deal"], ''The Guardian'' (14 July 2015).</ref> Obama stated that the agreement "meets every single one of the bottom lines we established when we achieved a framework earlier this spring. Every pathway to a nuclear weapon is cut off. And the inspection and transparency regime necessary to verify that objective will be put in place."<ref name="Lewis" /> The president emphasized that the agreement is "not built on trust—it is built on verification".<ref name="Gordon" /><ref name="Lewis" /> Obama vowed to veto any congressional action that would block the agreement's implementation, saying: "I am confident that this deal will meet the national security needs of the United States and our allies, so I will veto any legislation that prevents the successful implementation of this deal. We do not have to accept an inevitable spiral into conflict, and we certainly shouldn't seek it."<ref name="Lewis" /> Obama stated: "I welcome scrutiny of the details of this agreement" and added, "This is not the time for politics or posturing. Tough talk from Washington does not solve problems. Hard-nosed diplomacy, leadership that has united the world's major powers, offers a more effective way to verify that Iran is not pursuing a nuclear weapon."<ref name="Lewis" /> ** At a press briefing in Vienna, Secretary of State [[John Kerry]] said that the agreement was "a measureable step away from the prospect of nuclear proliferation" and "the specter of conflict" and "there can be no question that this agreement will provide a stronger, more comprehensive, and more lasting means of limiting Iran's nuclear program than any realistic alternative."<ref name="KerryPress" /> Kerry also stated, "The deal we have reached ... gives us the greatest assurance that we have had that Iran will not pursue a weapon covertly."<ref name="KerryPress" /> Addressing critics of the agreement, Kerry stated, "those who spend a lot of time suggesting that something could be better have an obligation to provide an alternative that, in fact, works" and "sanctioning Iran until it capitulates makes for a powerful talking point and a pretty good political speech, but it's not achievable outside a world of fantasy."<ref name="KerryPress" /> Kerry also stated, "we are under no illusions that the hard work is over. No one is standing here today to say that the path ahead is easy or automatic. We move now to a new phase—a phase that is equally critical and may prove to be just as difficult—and that is implementation."<ref name="KerryPress" /> ** [[Republican Party (United States)|Republicans]] lined up against the deal.<ref name="Hafezi">Parisa Hafezi, Louis Charbonneau, John Irish & Arshad Mohammed, [https://www.reuters.com/article/2015/07/14/us-iran-nuclear-idUSKCN0PM0CE20150714 "Iran deal reached, Obama hails step toward 'more hopeful world'"], Reuters (14 July 2015).</ref> The [[Republican Party presidential candidates, 2016|candidates for the Republican nomination for president in 2016]] uniformly condemned the deal; for example, [[Jeb Bush]] called the agreement "dangerous, deeply flawed, and short sighted" while [[Lindsey Graham]] asserted that the deal was a "death sentence for the state of Israel".<ref>Carrie Dann, [http://www.nbcnews.com/storyline/iran-nuclear-talks/2016-republican-candidates-slam-iran-nuke-deal-n391756 2016 "Republican Candidates Slam Iran Nuke Deal"], NBC News (14 July 2015).</ref><ref>Tom LoBianco & Sophie Tatum, [http://www.cnn.com/2015/07/14/politics/2016-candidates-iran-deal/ "GOP 2016 hopefuls slam Iran nuclear deal"], CNN (14 July 2015).</ref><ref name="Wollner">Adam Wollner, [http://www.nationaljournal.com/2016-elections/iran-deal-republican-presidential-candidates-20150714 "How the 2016 Presidential Candidates Are Reacting to the Iran Deal"], ''National Journal'' (14 July 2015).</ref> Former Obama advisor [[Daniel Pfeiffer]] tweeted, "none of these GOP contenders would end this Iran Deal if they got to the White House," and that it would "massively damage US in the world".<ref name="clairephipps">{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/live/2015/jul/14/iran-nuclear-talks-deal-historic-vienna-live-updates#block-55a4f252e4b07b3a9dbc7739 |title=Iran nuclear deal: historic agreement in Vienna|author=Claire Phipps |work=The Guardian}}</ref> ** [[Democratic Party presidential candidates, 2016|Candidates for the Democratic nomination for president in 2016]] welcomed the deal. Former Secretary of State [[Hillary Clinton]] called the agreement an "important step that puts the lid on Iran's nuclear programs"; Senator [[Bernie Sanders]] called it "a victory for diplomacy over saber-rattling" that "could keep the United States from being drawn into another never-ending war in the Middle East".<ref name="Wollner" /> ** [[Speaker of the United States House of Representatives|Speaker of the House]] [[John Boehner]], a Republican, called the JCPOA a "bad deal".<ref>{{cite news |first=David |last=Lawder |date=14 July 2015 |title=U.S. House Speaker Boehner says Iran accord looks like a 'bad deal' |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2015/07/14/iran-nuclear-boehner-deal-idUSL2N0ZU13820150714 |editor-first=Bill |editor-last=Trott |accessdate=15 July 2015}}</ref> ** [[House Minority Leader]] [[Nancy Pelosi]], a Democrat, said "I've closely examined this document. And it will have my strong support."<ref name="Kelly Pelosi">Nora Kelly, [http://www.nationaljournal.com/congress/nancy-pelosi-is-on-board-with-the-iran-nuclear-deal-20150716 "Nancy Pelosi Is On Board With the Iran Nuclear Deal"], ''National Journal'' (16 July 2015).</ref> Pelosi said that the agreement was "the product of years of tough, bold, clear-eyed leadership on the part of President Obama" and called it "a strong, effective option, for keeping the peace and stopping the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction".<ref name="Kelly Pelosi"/> ** [[Party leaders of the United States Senate|Senate Majority Leader]] [[Mitch McConnell]], a Republican, opposed the agreement, saying "The comprehensive nuclear agreement announced today appears to further the flawed elements of April's interim agreement because the Obama Administration approached these talks from a flawed perspective: reaching the best deal acceptable to Iran, rather than actually advancing our national goal of ending Iran's nuclear program."<ref>{{cite news |title=McConnell: Iran Deal a Result of 'Flawed Perspective' |url=http://abcnewsradioonline.com/politics-news/mcconnell-iran-deal-a-result-of-flawed-perspective.html |publisher=[[ABC News Radio]] |date=14 July 2015 |accessdate=24 July 2015}}</ref> ** [[Senate Minority Leader]] [[Harry Reid]], a Democrat, issued a brief statement on 14 July saying that the agreement was the result of years of hard work and, "now it is incumbent on Congress to review this agreement with the thoughtful, level-headed process an agreement of this magnitude deserves."<ref name="ReidReview">Reuters, [https://www.reuters.com/article/2015/07/14/iran-nuclear-congress-reid-idUSL2N0ZU0W720150714 "Reid calls for 'level-headed' review of Iran nuclear deal"] (14 July 2015).</ref> On 23 August, Reid endorsed the agreement, saying that the agreement "is the best path to stop Iran from obtaining a nuclear weapon" and that he would "do everything in my power to ensure that it stands".<ref>Associated Press, [https://www.nytimes.com/aponline/2015/08/23/us/politics/ap-us-congress-iran-deal.html "Reid Says He's Going to Support Obama's Iran Nuclear Deal"], ''The New York Times'' (23 August 2015).</ref> ** [[Senate Armed Services Committee]] Chairman [[John McCain]], a Republican, pledged to hold hearings on the deal during the sixty-day congressional review period and said that he is "totally opposed to" the agreement.<ref name="Mimms">Sarah Mimms, [http://www.nationaljournal.com/congress/the-gop-s-iran-deal-point-man-is-holding-his-fire-20150714 The GOP's Iran Deal Point Man Is Holding His Fire], ''National Journal'' (14 July 2015).</ref> [[Senate Foreign Relations Committee]] chairman [[Bob Corker]], another Republican, also opposed the deal, saying that he believed that the West had conceded too much.<ref name=corker>{{cite news |first=Mary |last=Troyan |title=Corker warns of 'breathtaking' concessions on Iran deal |url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/2015/06/15/corker-says-back-away-from-iran-deal/71260448/}}</ref> ** ''[[The New York Times]]'' editorial board wrote that the agreement "is potentially one of the most consequential accords in recent diplomatic history, with the ability not just to keep Iran from obtaining a nuclear weapon but also to reshape Middle East politics". They wrote: "It would be irresponsible to squander this chance to rein in Iran's nuclear program."<ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/2015/07/15/opinion/an-iran-nuclear-deal-that-reduces-the-chance-of-war.html "An Iran Nuclear Deal That Reduces the Chance of War"] (Editorial), ''The New York Times'' (14 July 2015).</ref> ** On May 8, 2018, President [[Donald Trump]] called the agreement "a horrible one-sided deal that should have never, ever been made"<ref name="auto1"/> and announced the [[United States of America]] would withdraw from the agreement.<ref>{{cite web|title=Trump: U.S. 'Will Withdraw' From Iran Nuclear Deal|url=https://www.npr.org/2018/05/08/609383603/trump-u-s-will-withdraw-from-iran-nuclear-deal|website=NPR|accessdate=8 May 2018}}</ref>
====From other countries==== * {{flagu|Holy See}} ** [[Holy See|The Vatican]] applauded the deal, saying in a statement: "The agreement on the Iranian nuclear program is viewed in a positive light by the Holy See."<ref>Antonia Blumberg, [http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/vatican-iran-nuclear-deal_55a55160e4b0a47ac15d8f6d "Vatican Says It Views Iran Deal In a 'Positive Light'"], The Huffington Post (14 July 2015).</ref> * {{flagu|Israel}} ** Prime Minister [[Benjamin Netanyahu]] said: "Israel is not bound by this deal with Iran, because Iran continues to seek our destruction, we will always defend ourselves."<ref>{{cite news |author1=Itamar Sharon |author2=Jonathan Beck |author3=Avi Lewis |url=http://www.timesofisrael.com/world-powers-nuclear-deal-with-iran-july-14-2015/ |title=Netanyahu: Israel 'not bound' by Iran deal, will defend itself |date=14 July 2015 |publisher=The Times of Israel |accessdate=14 July 2015}}</ref> Netanyahu called the deal a "capitulation" and "a bad mistake of historic proportions".<ref name="Beaumont">Peter Beaumont, [https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/jul/14/netanyahu-denounces-iran-nuclear-dealcriticism-israel "Netanyahu denounces Iran nuclear deal but faces criticism from within Israel"], ''The Guardian'' (14 July 2015).</ref> Deputy Foreign Minister [[Tzipi Hotovely]] called the deal an "historic surrender" and said that Israel would "act with all means to try and stop the agreement being ratified"—indicating that it would try to use its influence to block the agreement in the [[114th United States Congress|U.S. Congress]],<ref name="Hafezi" /> [[Naftali Bennett]], leader of the [[The Jewish Home|Bayit Yehudi]] party (which is a member of the [[Thirty-fourth government of Israel|government coalition]]), said: "The history books have been rewritten again today, and this period will be deemed particularly grave and dangerous."<ref name="Beaumont" /> ** Most Israelis were similarly critical of the agreement.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.timesofisrael.com/poll-israelis-overwhelmingly-certain-iran-still-wants-nukes/ |title=Poll: Israelis overwhelmingly certain Iran still wants nukes |date=16 July 2015 |publisher=The Times of Israel}}</ref> Netanyahu's leading political opponent, [[Zionist Union]] leader [[Isaac Herzog]], opposed the deal, stating that it "will unleash a lion from the cage" and make Iran "a nuclear-threshold state in a decade or so";<ref>{{cite magazine |title=Israeli Opposition Leader: Iran Deal Will Bring Chaos to the Middle East |url=https://www.theatlantic.com/international/archive/2015/07/israel-isaac-herzog-iran-nuclear-deal/398705/ |first=Jeffrey |last=Goldberg |authorlink=Jeffrey Goldberg |date=16 July 2015 |work=The Atlantic}}</ref> another Zionist Union member of the [[Knesset]], [[Shelly Yachimovich]], called the JCPOA a "dangerous, damaging agreement"<ref name="Beaumont" /> [[Yair Lapid]], head of the opposition [[Yesh Atid]] party, called the agreement "Israel's biggest foreign policy failure since the establishment of the state".<ref>{{cite news |title=Lapid says Iran nuclear deal 'Israel's biggest foreign policy failure ever' |url=http://www.jpost.com/Breaking-News/Lapid-says-Iran-nuclear-deal-Israels-biggest-foreign-policy-failure-ever-409025 |first=Arik |last=Bender |date=15 July 2015 |work=The Jerusalem Post}}</ref> At the same time, many of these figures also criticized Netanyahu's diplomatic campaign against the plan, calling it ineffectual and counter-productive. Yachimovich said that Netanyahu should "immediately cease and desist from confronting the Americans".<ref name="Beaumont" /> Lapid called on the prime minister to resign,<ref name="Beaumont" /> stating: "I also am not thrilled by Obama's policies. But Netanyahu crossed a line that caused the White House to stop listening to Israel. In the last year we weren't even in the arena, we had no representative in Vienna, our intelligence cooperation was harmed, and the door to the White House was closed to us."<ref name="Beaumont" /> ** The head of the opposition [[Yisrael Beiteinu]] party, [[Avigdor Lieberman]], described the agreement as a "surrender to terror".<ref name="Beaumont" /> ** [[Zehava Gal-On]], head of the opposition [[Meretz]] party, voiced cautious support for the JCPOA, writing, "The agreement is not perfect, it does not turn Iran into lovers of Israel all of the sudden, but it does aim to prevent Iran from obtaining a bomb, regulate the international mechanisms to monitoring it and allows the international community to act if the agreement is violated."<ref name="Pileggi">Tamar Pileggi, [http://www.timesofisrael.com/arab-israeli-mks-welcome-iran-nuclear-agreement/ Arab Israeli MKs welcome Iran nuclear agreement], The Times of Israel (14 July 2015).</ref> ** The [[Joint List|Joint (Arab) List]] party of [[Arab Israeli]] MKs welcomed the agreement.<ref name="Pileggi" /> ** [[Ami Ayalon]], former head of the Israeli internal security service [[Shin Bet]] and former commander of the [[Israeli Navy]], said that the agreement was "the best option" for Israel, saying, "When negotiations began, Iran was two months away from acquiring enough material for a [nuclear] bomb. Now it will be 12 months."<ref name="Ayalon">Jonathan Alter, [http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2015/07/21/ex-intel-chief-iran-deal-good-for-israel.html "Ex-Intel Chief: Iran Deal Good for Israel"], 'he Daily Beast (21 July 2015).</ref> Ayalon said that opposition to the deal in Israel was "more emotional than logical".<ref name="Ayalon" /><ref name="GiacomoIsrael">Carol Giacomo, [http://takingnote.blogs.nytimes.com/2015/07/23/in-israel-some-support-the-iran-deal/ "In Israel, Some Support the Iran Deal"], ''The New York Times'' Taking Note blog (23 July 2015).</ref> [[Efraim Halevy]], the director of the Israeli intelligence agency [[Mossad]] from 1998 to 2002, wrote in support of the agreement in ''[[Yedioth Ahronoth]]'', arguing that the JCPOA includes "components that are crucial for Israel's security" and warning that a collapse of the agreement will leave Iran "free to do as it pleases".<ref name="GiacomoIsrael"/> Chuck Freilich, a former deputy national security adviser in Israel and current senior fellow at Harvard University's Belfer Center, wrote an [[op-ed]] for ''The New York Times'' arguing that the JCPOA is "a good deal for Israel" and that by avoiding the threat of a nuclear Iran, the agreement "will enable Israel to divert precious resources to more immediate threats" and to pressing domestic needs.<ref>Chuck Freilich, [https://www.nytimes.com/2015/07/20/opinion/a-good-deal-for-israel.html?_r=0 "Op-ed: A Good Deal for Israel"], ''The New York Times'' (20 July 2015).</ref> * {{flagu|Italy}} ** Prime Minister [[Matteo Renzi]] said: "The agreement sows new hope for a regional peace project. Italy will actively support this process, and will ensure that it can benefit all countries of the region, without exception, with the aim of reaching a Middle East finally stable, where all peoples can live in peace and security."<ref>[http://www.governo.it/Presidente/Comunicati/dettaglio.asp?d=79006 "Iran: Renzi satisfied for the nuclear deal"], Government of Italy (14 July 2015).</ref> * {{flagu|Kazakhstan}} ** Kazakhstan's President Nursultan Nazarbayev welcomed the progress in the implementation of the Joint Comprehensive Action Plan on the regulation of the situation around Iran's nuclear programme.<ref name=akordastatement>{{cite web |title=Statement by the President of the Republic of Kazakhstan in connection with progress in the implementation of the Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action on Iran's nuclear programme |url=http://www.akorda.kz/en/events/akorda_news/akorda_other_events/statement-by-the-president-of-the-republic-of-kazakhstan-in-connection-with-progress-in-the-implementation-of-the-joint-comprehensive-plan-o |publisher=Akorda}}</ref> ** President Nazarbayev said, "... in 2013 Almaty hosted two rounds of talks on Iran's nuclear program, which contributed to the resumption of negotiations between "P5+1" and Iran. We are proud that the results of those two rounds of talks in Almaty have served as foundation for JCPOA adopted two years later."<ref name=akordastatement/> * [[Arab states of the Persian Gulf]] ** {{flagu|Kuwait}}: [[Sabah al Ahmed al Jabbar al Sabah|Sabah bin Ahmad Al-Sabah]], the [[List of emirs of Kuwait|emir of Kuwait]], congratulated all the nations involved in the negotiations and hoped the deal would lead to stability in the region.<ref name="ArabWorld">Nabih Bulos, [http://www.latimes.com/world/middleeast/la-fg-arab-world-reaction-iran-deal-20150714-story.html "Iran deal: Arab world's cautious reaction reflects deep fault lines"], ''Los Angeles Times'' (14 July 2015).</ref> ** {{flag|Oman}}: Oman welcomed the agreement.<ref name="Oman">Sarah MacDonald, [http://timesofoman.com/article/64129/Oman/Government/His-Majesty-Sultan-Qaboos-bin-Said-lauded-for-peace-efforts-as-Oman-celebrates-Renaissance-Day "His Majesty lauded for his role as global peacemaker"], ''Times of Oman'' (22 July 2015).</ref> Oman and its leader, Sultan [[Qaboos bin Said al Said]], were praised for its key role in the talks by diplomats and leaders from both Iran and the P5+1.<ref name="Oman"/> Oman has good relations with both Iran and the United States and played a key role in the beginning of the talks; Oman offered to establish a back channel between Iran and the United States in 2009, and the first secret talks were held between U.S. and Iranian diplomats in July 2012 in [[Muscat, Oman|Muscat]].<ref>Jay Solomon, [https://www.wsj.com/articles/iran-wish-list-led-to-u-s-talks-1435537004 Secret Dealings With Iran Led to Nuclear Talks: Years of clandestine exchanges between the two countries helped build a foundation for nuclear negotiations], ''The Wall Street Journal'' (28 June 2015).</ref><ref>Christa Case Bryant, [http://www.csmonitor.com/World/Middle-East/Olive-Press/2013/1124/The-man-behind-secret-US-Iran-talks-Sultan-Qaboos "The man behind secret US-Iran talks: Sultan Qaboos"], ''The Christian Science Monitor'' (24 November 2013).</ref> ** {{flagu|Qatar}}: The government welcomed the agreement as a "significant step" toward enhancing regional peace and stability.<ref>[http://www.kuna.net.kw/ArticleDetails.aspx?id=2451551&language=en "Qatar Welcomes Iran Nuclear Deal"], Kuwait News Agency (15 July 2015).</ref> ** {{flagu|Saudi Arabia}}: On 14 July, the official [[Saudi Press Agency]] released a statement attributed to an "official source" saying, "The Kingdom of Saudi Arabia has always believed in the importance of reaching a deal regarding Iran's nuclear program that ensures preventing Iran from obtaining nuclear weapons and at the same time includes a specific, strict and permanent mechanism for inspecting all sites—including military ones—along with a mechanism for rapidly and effectively re-imposing sanctions in case Iran violates the deal."<ref>[http://www.spa.gov.sa/English/details.php?id=1380735 "Official Source on Nuclear Deal between Iran and P5+1 Group"], Saudi Press Agency (14 July 2015).</ref> U.S. Secretary of Defense [[Ashton B. Carter]] said that Saudi Arabia approved of the international agreement, even though "the Saudis, along with other [[Sunni Islam|Sunni]] Arab countries in the Persian Gulf, view the predominantly [[Shia Islam|Shiite]] Iran as a regional adversary."<ref name="CooperSaudi">Helene Cooper, [https://www.nytimes.com/2015/07/23/world/middleeast/iran-nuclear-deal-saudi-arabia.html?_r=0 "Saudi Arabia Approves of Iran Nuclear Deal, U.S. Defense Chief Says"], ''The New York Times'' (22 July 2015).</ref> The Saudis have undertaken a military campaign in Yemen against [[Houthi insurgency in Yemen|Iranian-backed Houthi insurgents]] there.<ref name="CooperSaudi"/> * Elsewhere in the [[Muslim world]] ** {{flagu|Afghanistan}}: [[President of Afghanistan|Afghan president]] [[Mohammad Ashraf Ghani]] congratulated "the government and people of Islamic Republic of Iran on the occasion and reiterates that the government of Afghanistan welcomes any efforts that result in expansion of political and economic relations between states as well as consolidation and strengthening of peace and stability in the region."<ref>Xinhua, [http://www.globalpost.com/article/6614878/2015/07/14/afghan-president-welcomes-iran-nuclear-deal "Afghan president welcomes Iran nuclear deal"] GlobalPost (14 July 2015).</ref> ** {{flagu|Egypt}}: The [[Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Egypt)|Egyptian foreign ministry]] said the deal will prevent an arms race in the Middle East. The statement expressed hopes that the Middle East can be free of all weapons of mass destruction, including nuclear weapons.<ref>{{cite news |title=Iran Nuclear Deal Reactions: Egypt Hopes Agreement Will Avoid Middle East Arms Race |url=http://www.ibtimes.com/iran-nuclear-deal-reactions-egypt-hopes-agreement-will-avoid-middle-east-arms-race-2008562 |newspaper=International Business Times |date=14 July 2015 |first=Clark |last=Mindock |accessdate=15 July 2015}}</ref> ** {{flagu|Iraq}}: The Iraqi government applauded the agreement.<ref name=ArabWorld /> ** {{flagu|Pakistan}}: The [[Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Pakistan)|Ministry of Foreign Affairs]] "welcomed" the agreement, saying, "reciprocal confidence-building measures ... auger well for peace and security in our region."<ref>{{cite news |agency=AFP |url=http://tribune.com.pk/story/920778/pakistan-global-powers-welcome-iran-nuclear-deal/ |title=Pakistan, global powers welcome Iran nuclear deal |newspaper=The Express Tribune |date=14 July 2015}}.</ref> Former President [[Asif Ali Zardari]] welcomed the deal as "a triumph of diplomacy and negotiations over coercion and hostility" and called upon the government to push forward with plans for construction of an [[Iran–Pakistan gas pipeline]].<ref>Mateen Haider, [http://www.dawn.com/news/1194615/zardari-welcomes-iran-nuclear-deal "Zardari welcomes Iran nuclear deal"], ''Dawn'' (15 July 2015).</ref> ** {{flagu|Syria}}: President [[Bashar al-Assad]], an [[Iran–Syria relations|Iranian ally]], called the agreement as "a great victory" and wrote in a letter to Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, the Iranian supreme leader, that the agreement would be a "major turning point in the history of Iran, the region and the world".<ref>AFP, [https://news.yahoo.com/syrias-assad-congratulates-key-ally-iran-nuclear-deal-000408772.html "Syria's Assad praises Iran deal as 'great victory'"], Yahoo! News (14 July 2015).</ref> ** {{flagu|Turkey}}: The [[Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Turkey)|Ministry of Foreign Affairs]] welcomed the agreement in a statement saying that its implementation would contribute to regional peace, security and stability.<ref>Deniz Arslan, [http://www.todayszaman.com/diplomacy_turkey-welcomes-irans-nuclear-deal-with-west_393718.html "Turkey welcomes Iran's nuclear deal with West"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150721045139/http://www.todayszaman.com/diplomacy_turkey-welcomes-irans-nuclear-deal-with-west_393718.html |date=21 July 2015 }}, ''Today's Zaman'' (14 July 2015).</ref> Observers noted that although Turkey would benefit economically from the lifting of sanctions in the future, Turkish officials seemed to be "uneasy" of the potential for Iran to reemerge as a [[regional power]] that might overshadow Turkey.<ref>Cengiz Çandar, [https://www.usnews.com/news/articles/2015/07/21/how-turkey-really-feels-about-the-iran-deal "How Turkey Really Feels About the Iran Deal"], ''U.S. News & World Report'', Al-Monitor (21 June 2015).</ref> * Other countries ** {{flagu|Australia}}: [[Minister for Foreign Affairs (Australia)|Minister for Foreign Affairs]] [[Julie Bishop]] endorsed the agreement, saying: "What it has done is [bring] Iran into the international regime of inspections of nuclear programs, and that is a good thing. I think we have to give this comprehensive plan a chance."<ref>Katharine Murphy, [https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2015/jul/15/tony-abbott-welcomes-iran-nuclear-deal-with-great-caution "Tony Abbott welcomes Iran nuclear deal – with great caution"], ''The Guardian'' (14 July 2015).</ref> ** {{flagu|Canada}}: [[Minister of Foreign Affairs (Canada)|Foreign Minister]] [[Rob Nicholson]] stated at the time of the announcement: "We appreciate the efforts of the P5+1 to reach an agreement. At the same time, we will continue to judge Iran by its actions not its words. To this end, Canada will continue to support the efforts of the International Atomic Energy Agency to monitor Iran's compliance with its commitments."<ref>[http://www.international.gc.ca/media/aff/news-communiques/2015/07/14a.aspx?lang=eng "Minister Nicholson Comments on Nuclear Deal Reached by P5+1 and Iran"], Canadian Department of Foreign Affairs, Trade and Development (14 July 2015).</ref> ''[[The Globe and Mail]]'' reported at the time that Canada would keep its sanctions in place, at least initially, although Canada's own sanctions will have little impact on the Iranian economy.<ref>Graham Clark, [https://web.archive.org/web/20150716073810/http://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/politics/canada-says-iran-remains-significant-threat-to-peace-security/article25499682/ "Canada to keep sanctions against Iran despite nuclear deal"], ''The Globe and Mail'' (14 July 2015).</ref> While the Canadian government under Prime Minister [[Stephen Harper]] was opposed to the agreement, the [[29th Canadian Ministry|new Canadian government]] under Prime Minister [[Justin Trudeau]] supported it, and in February 2016, following the implementation of the agreement, Canada lifted most of its sanctions on Iran.<ref>John Paul Tasker, [http://www.cbc.ca/news/politics/trudeau-iran-sanctions-1.3442614 "Analysis: Iran sanctions lifted by Canada, but Justin Trudeau still faces 'delicate dance'"], CBC News (13 February 2016).</ref> ** {{flagu|Colombia}}: [[President of Colombia|President]] [[Juan Manuel Santos]] applauded the agreement as "another triumph of diplomacy over confrontation" and praised President Obama and Secretary of State Kerry for their "courage" in securing the deal.<ref>Adriaan Alsema, [http://colombiareports.com/santos-says-iran-nuclear-deal-is-another-triumph-of-diplomacy-over-confrontation/ "Santos says Iran nuclear deal is 'another triumph of diplomacy over confrontation'"], ''Colombia Reports'' (14 July 2015).</ref> ** {{flagu|India}}: The Indian embassy in Tehran stated, "India welcomes the announcement of lifting of nuclear-related sanctions against Iran. The milestone represents a significant success for patient diplomacy and signals a new chapter of peace and prosperity. India looks forward to further developing its longstanding, close, and mutually beneficial economic cooperation with Iran, including in the spheres of energy and regional connectivity."<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.tehrantimes.com/index_View.asp?code=252273|title=India welcomes JCPOA implementation|date=17 January 2016|newspaper=Tehran Times |accessdate=6 January 2018}}</ref> ** {{flagu|North Korea}}: The [[Foreign relations of North Korea|Foreign Ministry]] said that North Korea had no interest in a nuclear disarmament agreement, saying: "We do not have any interest at all on dialogue for unilaterally freezing or giving up our nukes."<ref>James Pearson & Seung Yun Oh, [https://www.reuters.com/article/2015/07/21/us-northkorea-nuclear-idUSKCN0PV0BG20150721 "North Korea says not interested in Iran-like nuclear talks with U.S."], Reuters (21 July 2015).</ref> ** {{flagu|Norway}}: In a statement, [[Minister of Foreign Affairs (Norway)|Foreign Minister]] [[Børge Brende]] said: "This historic agreement will benefit the international community, the Middle East and Iran. It will also pave the way for closer political and economic contact with Iran."<ref>[http://www.thelocal.no/20150714/norway-hails-historic-iran-deal "Norway hails 'historic' Iran deal"], ''The Local'' (14 July 2015).</ref> ** {{flagu|Philippines}}: The [[Department of Foreign Affairs (Philippines)|Department of Foreign Affairs]] welcomed the agreement, saying that it was an important measure to promote both regional and global security. They also called on the international community to maintain the positive momentum for long-term peace created by the agreement.<ref>{{cite web |title=Statement on the Iran Nuclear Deal |url=http://www.dfa.gov.ph/newsroom/dfa-releases/6854-statement-on-the-iran-nuclear-deal |publisher=Department of Foreign Affairs |accessdate=17 July 2015}}</ref>
====From international organizations==== * {{flagu|United Nations}} ** [[Secretary-General of the United Nations]] [[Ban Ki-moon]] issued a statement saying: "I warmly welcome the historic agreement in Vienna today and congratulate the P5+1 and Iran for reaching this agreement. This is testament to the value of dialogue. ... The United Nations stands ready to fully cooperate with the parties in the process of implementing this historic and important agreement."<ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/live/iran-nuclear-deal-live-updates/u-n-leader-welcomes-iran-deal/ "U.N. Leader Welcomes Iran Deal"], ''The New York Times'' (14 July 2015).</ref><ref>[https://www.un.org/apps/news/story.asp?NewsID=51409 UN applauds 'historic' deal on Iranian nuclear programme], UN News Centre (14 July 2015).</ref> ** [[International Atomic Energy Agency]] (IAEA) – Director General [[Yukiya Amano]] welcomed the agreement and congratulated Iran, the P5+1 countries and the European Union and said he is confident that IAEA is capable of doing the necessary monitoring and verification activities when requested.<ref>[https://www.iaea.org/newscenter/pressreleases/director-general%E2%80%99s-statement-announcement-e3/eu-3-and-iran-agreement-joint-comprehensive-plan-action "Director General's Statement on the Announcement by the E3/EU + 3 and Iran on the Agreement of the Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action"], International Atomic Energy Agency (14 July 2015).</ref> * Other international organizations and figures ** {{flagu|NATO}} [[Secretary General of NATO|Secretary General]] [[Jens Stoltenberg]] called the agreement a "historic breakthrough" and stated: "It is critical for Iran to implement the provisions of today's agreement and to fulfill all its international obligations and advance security in the region and beyond."<ref>[http://www.nato.int/cps/en/natohq/news_121818.htm "Statement on Iran Nuclear agreement"], North Atlantic Treaty Organization (15 July 2015).</ref> ** {{flagu|Arab League}} [[List of Secretaries General of the Arab League|Secretary-General]] [[Nabil Elaraby]] said he hoped the JCPOA would bring "stability and security" to the Middle East.<ref>Doug Bolton, [https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/middle-east/arab-league-chief-nabil-elaraby-calls-out-double-standard-of-international-attitude-to-israeli-nuclear-programme-10395236.html "Arab League chief Nabil Elaraby calls out 'double standard' of international attitude to Israeli nuclear programme"], ''The Independent'' (16 July 2015).</ref> ** {{flagu|Gulf Cooperation Council}} – The [[Gulf Cooperation Council]] publicly announced backing for the agreement at a 2 August 2015 summit in [[Doha]], [[Qatar]].<ref name="GCC">Jay Solomon & Carol E. Lee, [https://www.wsj.com/articles/gulf-arab-states-voice-support-for-iran-nuclear-deal-1438618887 "Gulf Arab States Voice Support for Iran Nuclear Deal"], ''The Wall Street Journal'' (3 August 2015).</ref> [[Khalid bin Mohammad Al Attiyah|Khalid al-Attiyah]], the foreign minister of Qatar (which currently chairs the GCC) said at a news conference with U.S. Secretary of State Kerry following the summit, "This was the best option amongst other options in order to try to come up with a solution for the nuclear weapons of Iran though dialogue, and this came up as a result of the efforts exerted by the United States of America and its allies. [Secretary Kerry] let us know that there's going to be a kind of live oversight for Iran not to gain or to get any nuclear weapons. This is reassuring to the region."<ref name="GCC"/> ** [[Association of Southeast Asian Nations]] – On 6 August 2015, following the 5th East Asia Summit Foreign Ministers' Meeting, the foreign ministers of the 10 ASEAN nations, along with the foreign ministers of India, Japan, New Zealand and South Korea, endorsed the deal, welcoming it as an "important resolution" to a pressing global concern.<ref name="Lee">Matthew Lee, [https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/world/asian-nations-endorse-iran-nuke-deal-as-kerry-says-hiroshima-anniversary-shows-accords-import/article25857062/ "Asian nations endorse Iran nuke deal as Kerry says Hiroshima anniversary shows accord's import"], ''The Globe and Mail'' (6 August 2015).</ref><ref>[https://www.state.gov/r/pa/prs/ps/2015/08/245757.htm "Statement on the Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action To Address Iran's Nuclear Programme by Ministers Participating in The 5th East Asia Summit Foreign Ministers' Meeting"], U.S. State Department (6 August 2015).</ref> Shortly before the joint ASEAN statement was released, U.S. Secretary of State Kerry met Japanese Foreign Minister [[Fumio Kishida]] in [[Kuala Lumpur]] to mark the 70th anniversary of the [[atomic bombing of Hiroshima]].<ref name="Lee"/> ** [[Mohamed ElBaradei]], former director general of the International Atomic Energy Agency, hailed the agreement as a triumph of diplomacy.<ref name="clairephipps" /> ** The [[International Crisis Group]] called the deal "a triumph of nuclear diplomacy" and urged both the [[United States Congress]] and [[Iranian Majlis]] to approve it.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.crisisgroup.org/en/publication-type/media-releases/2015/middle-east-north-africa/statement-the-triumph-of-nuclear-diplomacy.aspx |title=The Triumph of Nuclear Diplomacy |publisher=International Crisis Group}}</ref>
===Expert reactions=== Following the unveiling of the agreement, "a general consensus quickly emerged" among nuclear experts and watchdogs that the agreement "is as close to a best-case situation as reality would allow".<ref name="MehtaOpall-Rome">Aaron Mehta & Barbara Opall-Rome, [http://www.defensenews.com/story/defense/policy-budget/2015/07/18/experts-praise-iran-deal-despite-congressional-concerns/30261893/ "Experts Praise Iran Deal, Despite Congressional Concerns"], ''[[Defense News]]'' (18 July 2015).</ref> In August 2015, 75 arms control and nuclear nonproliferation experts signed a statement endorsing the deal as "a net-plus for international nuclear nonproliferation efforts" that exceeds the historical standards for arms control agreements.<ref>Michael Crowley, [http://www.politico.com/story/2015/08/nuclear-experts-fall-in-behind-obama-iran-121459 "Nuclear experts fall in behind Obama: The deal with Iran exceeds historical standards for arms control agreements, 75 experts say"], ''Politico'' (18 August 2015).</ref> The ''[[Bulletin of the Atomic Scientists]]'' invited top international security experts to comment on the final agreement.<ref name="Mecklin">John Mecklin, [http://thebulletin.org/experts-assess-iran-agreement-20158507 "The experts assess the Iran agreement of 2015"], ''Bulletin of the Atomic Scientists'' (14 July 2015).</ref> * [[Jeffrey Lewis (academic)|Jeffrey Lewis]], arms control expert and director of the East Asia Nonproliferation Program at the [[Monterey Institute of International Studies]], reviewed the final agreement and gave it a positive assessment, saying that he would give it an "A" grade.<ref name="Fisher">Max Fisher, [https://www.vox.com/2015/7/15/8967147/iran-nuclear-deal-jeffrey-lewis "'I would give it an A': Why nuclear experts love the Iran deal"], Vox (15 July 2015).</ref> While Lewis was skeptical about the chances of a workable deal emerging in 2014, during the negotiations, Lewis said that the final agreement was "a good deal because it slows down [the Iranian] nuclear program ... And it puts monitoring and verification measures in place that mean if they try to build a bomb, we're very likely to find out, and to do so with enough time that we have options to do something about it. There's a verifiable gap between their bomb option and an actual bomb. That's why it's a good deal."<ref name="Fisher" /> Lewis said that the final agreement was very similar to the April 2015 framework agreement.<ref name="Fisher" /> Lewis does not believe that the agreement will fundamentally alter the U.S.-Iranian relationship, seeing the agreement instead as "a really straightforward measure to slow down an enrichment program that was going gangbusters".<ref name="Fisher" /> * [[Lawrence Korb]] and Katherine Blakeley, senior fellow and policy analyst, respectively, at the [[Center for American Progress]], wrote that the agreement was "one of the most comprehensive and detailed nuclear arms agreements ever reached".<ref name="Mecklin" /> Korb and Blakeley wrote, "a good look at the three main legs of the agreement shows that this deal is, in fact, a good one, for the United States and for the international community."<ref name="Mecklin" /> Korb and Blakey said that the agreement "precludes Iranian development of a nuclear weapon by shutting down all of the pathways Iran might use to accumulate enough nuclear material to make a weapon" and praised components of the agreement which keep Iran subject to the constraints of the [[Nuclear Non-proliferation Treaty]], provides for robust IAEA monitoring and verification, and links the phased lifting of nuclear-related sanctions to IAEA verification of Iranian compliance.<ref name="Mecklin" /> * [[Frank von Hippel]], senior research physicist and professor of public and international affairs emeritus at the Program on Science and Global Security at [[Princeton University]], wrote, "The July 14 agreement is a political miracle" in which "Iran has agreed to back away from the nuclear-weapon threshold in exchange for a lifting of nuclear-related sanctions."<ref name="Mecklin" /> Von Hippel wrote, "The Obama administration argues—and I agree—that the ratcheting back of Iran's enrichment capacity will give the world a much longer warning time should Iran attempt to build a bomb."<ref name="Mecklin" /> Von Hippel suggested that once the first ten years of the agreement were complete, "One option that should be explored is multinational ownership and management of Iran's enrichment complex by a group of countries—perhaps including the United States."<ref name="Mecklin" /> * [[Frederick H. Fleitz]], former CIA nonproliferation analyst and currently of the [[Center for Security Policy]], wrote, "The provisions of this agreement ... contains minor concessions by Iran but huge concessions by the United States that will Iran to continue its nuclear program with weak verification provisions. Conditions for sanctions relief will be very easy for Iran to meet. Iran will not only continue to enrich uranium under the agreement, it will continue to develop advanced centrifuges that will reduce the timeline to an Iranian nuclear bomb."<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.foxnews.com/opinion/2015/07/14/iran-nuclear-deal-much-worse-than-experts-predicted.html |title=Iran nuclear deal much worse than experts predicted |author=Fleitz, Fred}}</ref> * William H. Tobey, senior fellow at Harvard University's [[Belfer Center for Science and International Affairs]], was critical of the agreement, writing that given Iranian hostility to the United States and Israel, the agreement provides little "more than a speed bump on the path to Iran's nuclear ambition".<ref name="Mecklin" /> Tobey wrote that that "speed bump" is not "a good trade for at least $150 billion in sanctions relief".<ref name="Mecklin" /> * Kingston Reif, director for disarmament and threat reduction policy at the [[Center for Arms Control and Non-Proliferation]], said that although the JCPOA is "not perfect", it "will be a net plus for nonproliferation and will enhance U.S. and regional security".<ref name="Mecklin" /> Reif wrote that it was "clear that Tehran had to retreat from many of its initial demands, including in the areas of the scale of uranium enrichment it needed, the intrusiveness of inspections it would tolerate, and the pace of sanctions relief it would demand".<ref name="Mecklin" /> Reif also wrote that the JCPOA "will keep Iran further away from the ability to make nuclear weapons for far longer than the alternative of additional sanctions or a military strike possibly could", and as a result, the threat of regional proliferation throughout the Middle East was diminished.<ref name="Mecklin" /> Reif added: "A perfect deal was not attainable. Overall, it's a very strong and good deal, but it wasn't negotiations that resulted in a score of 100-0 for the [United States]. That's not how international negotiations go. ... The monitoring and verification regime in this deal is the most comprehensive and intrusive regime that has ever been negotiated."<ref name="MehtaOpall-Rome"/> * [[Siegfried S. Hecker]] of the [[Center for International Security and Cooperation]] at [[Stanford University]] wrote, "the Iran nuclear deal was hard-won and is better than any other reasonably achievable alternative."<ref name="Mecklin" /> Hecker wrote, "Iran agreed to considerably greater restrictions on its program than what I thought was possible."<ref name="Mecklin" /> Hecker's view is that it is "imperative that the international community develops a credible and decisive response in the event of an Iranian violation of the agreement".<ref name="Mecklin" /> He noted, "this agreement was one of the most technically informed diplomatic negotiations I have seen," with both sides advised by "world-class nuclear scientists": U.S. Secretary of State Kerry by U.S. Secretary of Energy Moniz, and Iranian Foreign Minister Zarif by [[Atomic Energy Organization of Iran]] chief [[Ali-Akbar Salehi]].<ref name="Mecklin" /> * [[Zia Mian]] of the Program on Science & Global Security at [[Princeton University]] wrote that the JCPOA offers three "important lessons for those wanting to make progress towards nuclear disarmament and a more peaceful world".<ref name="Mecklin" /> The first lesson was, "nuclear diplomacy can work. But it requires hard political work of many kinds"; Mian praised both the "creative technical and policy analysis work from within and outside governments to create options for negotiators to find common ground" as well as "the patient grassroots work to engage and mobilize public constituencies that brought to power leaders in the United States and in Iran willing to engage with each other and to take risks for a more peaceful relationship between their countries".<ref name="Mecklin" /> The second lesson was, "International nuclear politics is bound to domestic politics, for good and ill. The Iran agreement has come despite determined hostility from conservatives within the United States, Israel, Saudi Arabia, the [[Arab states of the Persian Gulf|Gulf states]], and Iran. Seeing the world as a hierarchy shaped by power and fear, and locked in rigid, exclusivist national or religious identities, they press for advantage and privilege or to maintain the status quo. Sharing a propensity for mistrust, coercion, and violence, they would risk war with those they see as enemies rather than try dialogue and possible agreement on a peaceful future based on the ideals of equity and respect for others. These opponents will derail the Iran deal if they can."<ref name="Mecklin" /> The third lesson is, "nuclear disarmament issues do not exist in isolation"; Mian called for more foreign minister-level talks in the Middle East, rather than expanded U.S. military assistance in the region.<ref name="Mecklin" /> * [[Ernest Moniz]], [[United States Secretary of Energy|U.S. Secretary of Energy]] and a nuclear physicist and former professor at the [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology]] who was a key member of the U.S. negotiating team, stated that the JCPOA helps put Iran further from a nuclear weapon not only in the first fifteen years, with "lots of very, very explicit constraints on the program that roll back current activities", but also beyond that period, because the agreement commits Iran to join the [[Additional Protocol]].<ref>[https://www.npr.org/2015/07/15/423263262/u-s-energy-secretary-deal-keeps-iran-further-away-from-a-nuclear-weapon "U.S. Energy Secretary: Deal Keeps Iran Further Away From A Nuclear Weapon"], ''All Things Considered'', NPR (15 July 2015).</ref><ref>Kristina Peterson & Amy Harder, [https://www.wsj.com/articles/the-nuclear-physicist-answering-lawmakers-questions-on-iran-deal-1437084084 "The Nuclear Physicist Answering Lawmakers' Questions on Iran Deal"], ''The Wall Street Journal'' (16 July 2015).</ref> Former IAEA Deputy Director [[Olli Heinonen]] and former Iraq weapons inspector David Albright expressed concerns with the length of a review process for inspecting undeclared facilities, stating that a delay up to a maximum of 24 days was too long.<ref name="VerificationNYT">{{cite news |title=Verification Process in Iran Deal Is Questioned by Some Experts |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/07/23/world/middleeast/provision-in-iran-accord-is-challenged-by-some-nuclear-experts.html |author=Gordon, Michael |work=The New York Times |date=23 July 2015}}</ref> Heinonen said, "it is clear that a facility of sizable scale cannot simply be erased in three weeks' time without leaving traces," but said there was a risk that the Iranians could hide small-scale work, such as creating uranium components of a nuclear weapon, particularly because they have experience with cheating.<ref name="VerificationNYT"/> Albright said that activities on "a small scale", such as experiments with [[high explosive]]s or a small plant to make centrifuges operation could possibly be cleared out in 24 days.<ref name="VerificationNYT"/> Former U.S. State Department official Robert J. Einhorn, who took part in P5+1 nuclear talks with Iran from 2009 to 2013, said, "a limit shorter than 24 days would have been desirable," but "it is probably the case that the greater the significance of a covert activity, the more difficult it will be to remove evidence of it in 24 days."<ref name="VerificationNYT"/> U.S. Energy Department officials said that if the Iranians attempted to conduct centrifuge test, uranium conversion, or other activities, contamination would be generated that is very difficult to conceal.<ref name="VerificationNYT"/> * At a September 2015 panel discussion at the [[University of California, Los Angeles]] (UCLA) with [[Albert Carnesale]] (a former [[SALT I]] negotiator), [[Dalia Dassa Kaye]] (of the RAND Corporation), and Aslı Bâli and Steven Spiegel of UCLA, the panelists came a general consensus that the JCPOA "should be given a chance to work" and "despite its flaws, the agreement was worth pursuing and that the alternative would have been no agreement at all."<ref name="McInerny">Peggy McInerny, [http://www.international.ucla.edu/institute/article/156987 "Give nuclear agreement with Iran a chance, say experts"], UCLA International Institute (21 September 2015).</ref> * [[Henner Fürtig]], a senior member of [[German Institute of Global and Area Studies]] and a professor at the [[University of Hamburg]] wrote that the accord contains multiple victories for all sides. It is a "triumph of international diplomacy" and "rarely reached consensus" for the United Nations and the UNSC, but "it is no panacea" resolving other conflicts in the Middle East.<ref>{{cite journal |first=Henner |last=Fürtig |title=The Nuclear Agreement with Iran: Successful Settling of an International Crisis |url=https://giga.hamburg/en/system/files/publications/gf_international_1506.pdf |journal=GIGA Focus |publisher=German Institute of Global and Area Studies |issn=2196-3940 |number=6 |year=2015}}</ref>
===In popular culture=== The American TV series ''[[Madam Secretary (TV series)|Madam Secretary]]'' built a whole [[Madam Secretary (season 1)|season]] around the negotiations.<ref>{{cite magazine |first=Robin |last=Wright |url=http://www.newyorker.com/news/news-desk/madam-secretary-and-the-real-iran-deal |title="Madam Secretary" and the Real Iran Deal |work=The New Yorker |date=4 May 2015 |access-date=19 October 2015}}</ref> Five years before the deal, in ''[[24 (TV series)|24]]''{{'}}s [[24 (season 8)|season 8]], the negotiations between the United States leaders and "President Hassan" of ''Islamic republic of Kamistan'' to abandon his nuclear technology programme was shown, which drew comparison to the US-Iran dispute.<ref>{{cite news |first=James |last=Reinl |url=http://www.thenational.ae/news/world/americas/un-finds-tv-show-too-hot-to-handle |title=UN finds TV show too hot to handle |work=[[The National (Abu Dhabi)|The National]] |date=7 February 2010|access-date=19 October 2015}}</ref> However the deal was contrarily to ''[[Homeland (TV series)|Homeland]]''{{'}}s [[Homeland (season 3)|season 3]] plot that "fueled nuclear paranoia" against Iran.<ref>{{cite news |first=John |last=Hendel |url=http://theweek.com/articles/455575/how-obamas-iran-deal-screwed-homelands-third-season |title=How Obama's Iran deal screwed up Homeland's third season |work=The Week |date=26 November 2013|access-date=19 October 2015}}</ref>
After the deal, a joke began circulating in Iran that the name of city of [[Arak, Iran|Arak]] would change to "Barack" in honor of Obama, and that in return, the United States would change the name of [[Manhattan]] borough to "''Mash Hassan''" ({{lang-fa|مش حسن}}) which is a very casual way of referring to Rouhani.<ref>{{cite news |first=Ali |last=Omidi |url=http://www.al-monitor.com/pulse/originals/2015/11/iran-us-syria-direct-bilateral-talks.html |title=Will Rouhani and Zarif defy Khamenei by holding direct talks with US on Syria? |work=Al-Monitor |date=17 November 2015|access-date=1 May 2016}}</ref>
[[Javad Zarif]]'s efforts in the negotiations drew comparisons to mythological [[Arash the Archer]], and two former Prime Ministers: [[Mohammad Mosaddegh]], who led the withdrawal of foreigners and [[nationalization of the Iranian oil industry]] and was overthrown by [[1953 Iranian coup d'état|American–British coup d'état]], because both fought foreigners for Iran's rights; and [[Amir Kabir]], because both faced domestic hostility through their way to gain more interest for the nation.<ref>{{cite news |first=Arash |last=Karimi |url=http://www.al-monitor.com/pulse/originals/2015/07/zarif-popular-foreign-minister-nuclear-deal.html |title=Zarif's domestic popularity soars with nuclear deal |work=Al-Monitor |date=14 July 2015|access-date=1 May 2016}}</ref>
===Public opinion surveys===
====United States (nationwide)==== Public polling on the issue has yielded varied and sometimes contradictory results, depending on the question wording,<ref>Ariel Edwards-Levy, [http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/iran-polls-wording_55aeab83e4b08f57d5d2ca33 "Contradictory Iran Polls Show Why It Matters How You Ask: People sometimes fall back on partisan cues when they lack information"], The Huffington Post (21 July 2015).</ref> whether the poll explains the provisions of the agreement, and whether an "undecided" option is offered.<ref>Greg Sargent, [https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/plum-line/wp/2015/08/03/what-does-the-american-public-really-think-of-the-iran-deal/ "What does the American public really think of the Iran deal?"], ''The Washington Post'' (3 August 2015).</ref> Polls have consistently shown polarization by party affiliation, with majorities of self-identified Democrats supporting the agreement and majorities of self-identified Republicans opposing it.<ref name="JordanYouGov">William Jordan, [https://today.yougov.com/news/2015/07/17/americans-tend-favor-iran-deal-they-doubt-it-will-/ "Americans tend to favor Iran deal, despite serious doubts"], YouGov (17 July 2015).</ref><ref name="CNNAugPoll">{{cite news August 2015}}</ref><ref name="PewPoll">{{cite news |url=http://www.people-press.org/2015/07/21/iran-nuclear-agreement-meets-with-public-skepticism/ |title=Iran Nuclear Agreement Meets With Public ====United States (specific communities)==== * According to a [[John Zogby|Zogby Research Services]] poll for the [[Public Affairs Alliance of Iranian Americans]], conducted 20–31 May 2015, 64% of Iranian Americans support the Iran deal, and 8 in 10 say it will improve Iran's relations with the West.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.paaia.org/CMS/paaia-releases-national-public-opinion-survey-of-iranian-americans-american-public.aspx |title=Iranian Americans and the American public at large support efforts to reach a nuclear agreement with Iran |publisher=PAAIA |author=Hannah Volmar |date=22 June 2015 |accessdate=14 August 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150812183300/http://www.paaia.org/CMS/paaia-releases-national-public-opinion-survey-of-iranian-americans-american-public.aspx |archivedate=12 August 2015 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> * A poll of American Jewish adults conducted by GBA Strategies for [[J Street]] (which supports the agreement) from 21–23 July found that 60 percent of American Jews support the agreement.<ref name="JBA Poll">[https://web.archive.org/web/20150730022415/http://jstreet.org/blog/post/new-poll-majority-of-american-jews-support-iran-nuclear-deal_1 "New Poll: Majority of American Jews Support Iran Nuclear Deal"], J Street (28 July 2015).</ref> The poll found that: "There is broad support for the agreement, regardless of age, gender, region, Jewish organizational engagement, and awareness about the agreement."<ref name="JBA Poll"/> The poll found that support was strong across every [[Jewish denominations|denomination]] except for [[Orthodox Judaism|Orthodox Jews]], with 67% of [[Reform Judaism|Reform Jews]] in support, 63% of Jews of no particular denomination in support, and 55% of [[Conservative Judaism|Conservative Jews]] in support.<ref name="JBA Poll"/> * According to a Quinnipiac poll taken 30 July – 4 August 43% of New York City voters oppose the agreement, while 36% support it; 42% said that the agreement would make the world less safe, while 40% said it will make the world more safe. Among Jewish voters in New York City, 33% support the agreement while 53% oppose it, and 51% say the agreement will make the world less safe, while 37% say that the agreement will make the world more safe.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.quinnipiac.edu/images/polling/nyc/nyc08112015_Nd74njf.pdf |title=New York City Voters Oppose Iran Nuclear Pact, Quinnipiac University Poll Finds |publisher=Quinnipiac University |author=Maurice Carroll |date=11 August 2015 |accessdate=13 August 2015}}</ref> * According to a [[Public Policy Polling]] poll of New York City voters taken 11–12 August, 58% of New York City voters support the Iran agreement, while 35% oppose it; 49% of New York City voters want their members of Congress to let the agreement go forward, while 33% want their members of Congress to block the agreement. The agreement achieved majority support from women and men; whites, African Americans, and Hispanics; and in every age group.<ref>Tom Jensen, [http://www.publicpolicypolling.com/main/2015/08/NYCMemoResults0815.pdf "New York City Voters Strongly Support Iran Deal"], Public Policy Polling (13 August 2015).</ref> * A [[GfK]] poll of American Jews conducted for the [[American Jewish Committee]] between 7 and 22 August found that American Jews narrowly favored the agreement with 50.6% approving and 47.2% disapproving.<ref>[http://forward.com/news/breaking-news/320816/jews-back-iran-deal-by-narrow-margin-poll-says/ "Jews Back Iran Deal by Narrow Margin, Poll Says"], ''The Forward'', Jewish Telegraphic Agency (11 September 2015).</ref>
====Iran==== * According to a poll conducted from 12–28 May 2015 by the [[University of Tehran]] Center for Public Opinion Research, the independent, Toronto-based firm [[IranPoll]], and the Center for International and Security Studies at the [[University of Maryland School of Public Policy]], 57% of Iranians support the deal, whereas 15% opposed it.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://cissm.umd.edu/news/majority-iranian-public-approves-pursuing-nuclear-agreement-new-study-finds |title=Majority of Iranian Public Approves of Pursuing Nuclear Agreement, New Study Finds |publisher=University of Maryland School of Policy |author1=Nancy Gallagher |author2=Ebrahim Mohseni |author3=Clay Ramsay |date=23 June 2015 |accessdate=14 August 2015}}</ref> * According to [[Vice President of Iran|First Vice President]] [[Eshaq Jahangiri]]'s interview on 6 August 2015, an Iranian government poll indicates that 80%-88% of Iranians support the Iran deal, whereas 4% oppose it.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.entekhab.ir/fa/news/219000 |title=جهانگیری: مخالفان توافق هسته ای 4 درصد هستند، پس لحن طلبکارانه نداشته باشند و در حد همان 4 درصد حرف بزنند |publisher=Entekhab |author=Entekhab |date=6 August 2015 |accessdate=14 August 2015}}</ref> * A poll conducted 27 May to 29 May 2015, by private [[Virginia]]-based Information and Public Opinion Solutions LLC (iPOS), suggests that a 63% majority of Iranians favor a deal, with 12% conditional approval (they would support it only if certain advantages for Iran are contained within a final agreement). Answering "If Iran and the West reach a nuclear deal, do you agree or disagree (with) a normalization of relations between Iran and the US?", 52% agreed and 20% disagreed. The poll was conducted by phone with a random sample of 680 Iranians 18-years-old and older.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nationalinterest.org/feature/sorry-hardliners-iran-wants-nuclear-deal-13068 |title=Iran Wants a Nuclear Deal |publisher=[[The National Interest]] |author=Geneive Abdo |accessdate=14 September 2015}}</ref>
====Germany==== * A July 2015 nationally representative survey of German adults conducted by YouGov Germany Omnibus found that overall, "63% of Germans support the deal to curb Iran's nuclear program, while only 18% oppose it and 20% don't know."<ref name="JordanYouGov"/>
==Process==
===Incorporated into international law by the United Nations Security Council=== {{main|United Nations Security Council Resolution 2231}} As provided for in the JCPOA, the agreement was formally endorsed by the UN Security Council,<ref name="Thomson">[http://www.cbc.ca/news/world/iran-nuclear-deal-un-security-council-likely-to-vote-next-week-1.3152376 "Iran nuclear deal: UN Security Council likely to vote next week: US diplomats to promote deal to UN counterparts in coming days"], CBC, Thomson Reuters (15 July 2015).</ref><ref name="Sengupta">Somini Sengupta, [https://www.nytimes.com/2015/07/16/world/consensus-gives-security-council-momentum-in-mideast-but-question-is-how-much.html Consensus Gives Security Council Momentum in Mideast, but Question Is How Much], ''The New York Times'' (16 July 2015).</ref> incorporating it into [[Public international law|international law]].<ref name="UNSCScheduled">CBS News/Associated Press, [http://www.cbsnews.com/news/un-security-council-vote-iran-nuclear-deal-resolution-us-congress-objections/ Iran deal set to become international law] (17 July 2015).</ref><ref name="UNSCRes">Somini Sengupta, [https://www.nytimes.com/2015/07/21/world/middleeast/security-council-following-iran-nuclear-pact-votes-to-lift-sanctions.html "U.N. Moves to Lift Sanctions on Iran After Nuclear Deal"], ''The New York Times'' (20 July 2015).</ref> There was initially disagreement on if the deal is legally binding on the United States.{{efn|The extent to which the JCPOA is legally binding on the United States—i.e., whether a future president could lawfully repudiate the JCPOA once it goes into effect—is a matter of dispute. Legal scholars [[Bruce Ackerman]] of [[Yale Law School]] and David Golove of the [[New York University School of Law]] argue that the Iran Nuclear Agreement Review Act of 2015 had the effect of making the agreement (once implemented) into a [[congressional-executive agreement]].<ref name="Nelson">Steven Nelson, [https://www.usnews.com/news/articles/2015/07/15/iran-deal-may-bind-next-president "Iran Deal May Bind Next President: Scholars say the nuclear agreement could be binding under domestic and international law"], ''U.S. News & World Report'' (15 July 2015).</ref> Golove states that the president cannot "ignore commitments [made by him or by a past president] in congressional-executive agreements without congressional authority to do so", and believes that the agreement is binding under international law, irrespective of any White House declaration, because it contains no provision saying otherwise.<ref name="Nelson"/><ref>David Golove, [https://www.justsecurity.org/14154/presidential-authority-conclude-iran-nuclear-agreement-and-senates-self-defeating-bill/ "Presidential Authority to Conclude an Iran Nuclear Agreement—and the Senate's Self-Defeating Bill"], Just Security (20 August 2014).</ref> Ackerman agrees, arguing, "Presidents do not have the power to repudiate congressional-executive agreements without strictly following the procedures laid out by Congress in its original authorizing legislation."<ref name="Nelson"/> Others, such as Michael Ramsey of the [[University of San Diego School of Law]], argue that unless Congress expressly approves of the agreement via a resolution of approval (which is unlikely), the agreement is nonbinding under domestic law, so that "this president can implement to the extent of his statutory and constitutional authority [and] future presidents can refuse to follow."<ref name="Nelson"/> Ramsey points out, however, that even if the agreement is a nonbinding executive agreement under domestic law, it may still be binding under international law, since domestic invalidity is not a defense to failure to follow an international agreement.<ref name="Nelson"/><br />The position of the U.S. government is different. Secretary of State Kerry stated in a Senate Foreign Relations Committee hearing, "with respect to the talks, we've been clear from the beginning. We're not negotiating a, quote, 'legally binding plan.' We're negotiating a plan that will have in it a capacity for enforcement."<ref>Michael J. Glennon, [https://www.justsecurity.org/21130/iran-nuclear-deal-dispensability-obligation/ "The Iran Nuclear Deal: The Dispensability of Obligation"], Just Security (16 March 2015).</ref> (Kerry also said that a future president is, as a practical matter, unlikely to "turn around and just nullify it" given the international agreement from the other P5+1 powers.<ref name="SchwartzBinding">Felicia Schwartz, [https://www.wsj.com/articles/iran-nuclear-deal-if-reached-wouldnt-be-legally-binding-kerry-says-1426115097 "Iran Nuclear Deal, If Reached, Wouldn't Be 'Legally Binding,' Kerry Says"], ''The Wall Street Journal'' (11 March 2015).</ref>) Several legal scholars support this argument. [[John B. Bellinger III]] argues: "The next president will have the legal right under both domestic and international law to scrap the JCPOA and reimpose U.S. nuclear sanctions on Iran."<ref name="Laub">Zachary Laub, [http://www.cfr.org/iran/binding-iran-deal/p36828 "How Binding Is the Iran Deal?"] (interview with John B. Bellinger III), Council on Foreign Relations (23 July 2015).</ref> Bellinger states that "such an action would be inconsistent with political commitments made by the Obama administration and would likely cause a major rift with U.S. allies and Iran to resume its nuclear activities," but that "would not constitute a violation of international law, because the JCPOA is not legally binding".<ref name="Laub"/> [[Orde Kittrie]] of [[Arizona State University]] similarly writes that the JCPOA is a kind of "nonbinding, unsigned political" agreement considered "more flexible than treaties or other legally binding international agreements".<ref name="Kittrie">{{cite news |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/congress-can-rewrite-the-iran-deal-1439419154 |title=Congress Can Rewrite the Iran Deal |work=The Wall Street Journal |author=[[Orde Kittrie]] |date=12 August 2015 |accessdate=16 August 2015}}</ref>}}
